messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chinese swords, Damascus, wootz, & Francis Boyd's collection
messages.msgSnippet: Hello: Ok my area of expertise is NOT exactly the Japanese sword..(although I have made quite a few using the same methods, materials...etc for my books...)
messages.messageBody:
Hello:

Ok my "area of expertise" is NOT exactly the Japanese sword..(although I
have made quite a few using the same methods, materials...etc for my
books...)

However there are numerous examples of various swords from the Bronze Age
that survive to this very day..so as far as what Mr Boyd says..I would TEND
to believe him at face value...however even the "best" of us can be mislead.

I CAN however "vouch" for the "Blood Rust" effect on blades as I have
seen it happen on various pieces I have restored..however the only pieces I
have seen it happen with are pieces from WWII and some from the "War to End
All Wars"..WWI.... Now I am not saying anything other than what I personally
have seen... now I do have some questions as far as this particular blade
goes..I find it interesting that in all the years and centuries past that no
one cleaned the blood off of said sword.. But this is "just me"...

JPH


Dr JP Hrisoulas, COL NANG (Ret)
Bladesmith.
Author: The Complete Bladesmith
The Master Bladesmith
The Pattern Welded Blade
http: _www.atar.com_ (http://www.atar.com/)

Hello,
I would like to read some about this from the specialists too.
For me it is unbelievable that a sword exists older than 1500 years.
Excuse my bad English, regards,
Eck

Eckhardt Hemkemeier
Dojoleiter

Am 20.04.2013 um 01:30 schrieb David Zincavage <jdz@...>:

> I thought the article was extremely interesting. I was a bit skeptical
> about the "blood rust" stuff and this chap owning the first Han
> Emperor's sword (dating from circa 200 B.C.). Mr. Boyd seemed to be
> implying that the greater part of the techniques used to produce
> Japanese swords were in use in China in deep Antiquity. I'd like to
> hear serious Nihonto experts responding to the article's claims. (And
> how about those Vincents? Not one, but two Vincents.)
>
> On 4/19/2013 7:00 PM, Dr. Philip Vos Fellman wrote:
> >
> > Hi Dave and All,
> >
> > I have been singing the praises of Francis Boyd for almost twenty
> > years now. I have ever been able to jst plunk down the dash and a
> > commission a piece fro him, but if I were to get a custom made
> > shinsakuto, I would want one from Francis above any other living
> > swordsmith. If you can spend some time with him, like the author did,
> > you will easily understand my sentiments. Thanks for sharing, Go Eli!
> >
> > Cheers,
> >
> > Phil
> >
> > Sent from my iPad

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chinese swords, Damascus, wootz, & Francis Boyd's collection
messages.msgSnippet: I thought the article was extremely interesting.  I was a bit skeptical about the blood rust stuff and this chap owning the first Han Emperor s sword (dating
messages.messageBody:
I thought the article was extremely interesting. I was a bit skeptical
about the "blood rust" stuff and this chap owning the first Han
Emperor's sword (dating from circa 200 B.C.). Mr. Boyd seemed to be
implying that the greater part of the techniques used to produce
Japanese swords were in use in China in deep Antiquity. I'd like to
hear serious Nihonto experts responding to the article's claims. (And
how about those Vincents? Not one, but two Vincents.)

On 4/19/2013 7:00 PM, Dr. Philip Vos Fellman wrote:
>
> Hi Dave and All,
>
> I have been singing the praises of Francis Boyd for almost twenty
> years now. I have ever been able to jst plunk down the dash and a
> commission a piece fro him, but if I were to get a custom made
> shinsakuto, I would want one from Francis above any other living
> swordsmith. If you can spend some time with him, like the author did,
> you will easily understand my sentiments. Thanks for sharing, Go Eli!
>
> Cheers,
>
> Phil
>
> Sent from my iPad

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chinese swords, Damascus, wootz, & Francis Boyd's collection
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Dave and All, I have been singing the praises of Francis Boyd for almost twenty years now. I have ever been able to jst plunk down the dash and a commission
messages.messageBody:
Hi Dave and All,

I have been singing the praises of Francis Boyd for almost twenty years now. I have ever been able to jst plunk down the dash and a commission a piece fro him, but if I were to get a custom made shinsakuto, I would want one from Francis above any other living swordsmith. If you can spend some time with him, like the author did, you will easily understand my sentiments. Thanks for sharing, Go Eli!

Cheers,

Phil

Sent from my iPad

On Apr 17, 2013, at 4:27 PM, David Zincavage <jdz@...> wrote:
